contentrichtext.text: '''Carlos Mastronardi''' (1901 - June 5, 1976) was an [[Argentina|Argentine]] journalist, poet, and translator. His works included ''Luz de provincia'', ''Tierra amanecida'' (1926), ''Conocimiento de la noche'' (1937), and ''Tratado de la pena''. His non-fiction ''[[Paul Valéry|Valéry]] o la infinitud del método'' (''Valéry, or the infinitude of method'') won the [[Buenos Aires]] Municipal Prize for Literature (1955). Other important works of non-fiction included ''Formas de la realidad nacional'' (''Forms of the National Reality'', 1961) and ''Memorias de un Provinciano'' (''Memoirs of a Man from the Provinces'', 1967). Some of his journalism was published posthumously as ''Cuadernos de vivir y pensar'' (''Notebooks of Living and Thinking'', 1984).<ref>mostly from Prieto, "Memorias…"; ''Tratado de la pena'' and the Municipal Prize for Literature are mentioned in Efemérides' "Algunos amigos…".</ref> As a translator, Mastronardi was mainly known for translating the French [[Symbolist poetry|Symbolist]] poets into Spanish. As a poet, although identified personally with the ''[[avant-garde]]'' of his time, he wrote largely in traditional forms rather than free verse, and rejected what he viewed as his contemporaries' excessive use of metaphor.<ref name="Prieto, Memorias…">Prieto, "Memorias…"</ref> Born in [[Gualeguay, Entre Ríos|Gualeguay]],<ref name="Prieto, Memorias…"/> [[Entre Ríos Province]],<ref name="Efemérides, Algunos amigos…">Efemérides, "Algunos amigos…"</ref> Mastronardi came to Buenos Aires at the age of 19. There he became a member of the [[Florida group|Martín Fierro group (also known as the Florida group)]] and an intimate of [[Jorge Luis Borges]], although they disagreed strongly about questions about aesthetics and poetry.<ref name="Prieto, Memorias…"/> Mastronardi figures as a minor character in Borges's short story ''[[Tlön, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius]]''.<ref>Borges, "Tlön…</ref> Mastronardi led a notoriously nocturnal existence. Writing of Mastronardi in 1986 in the newspaper ''El País'' (Madrid), Borges said of Mastronardi that "Like [[C. Auguste Dupin|Auguste Dupin]] ... <nowiki>[</nowiki>the detective character created by [[Edgar Allan Poe]]<nowiki>]</nowiki> ... at night he went about the streets of Buenos Aires looking for that intellectual stimulus that only can be given by nighttime in a great city." <ref name="Efemérides, Algunos amigos…"/> After a long period in which his work fell into obscurity, Mastronardi's works are ({{As of|2003|lc=on}}) being re-published by Argentina's Universidad Nacional del Litoral.<ref name="Prieto, Memorias…"/> == Quotation == "Lyric poetry, for many of its ... [Argentine] ... practitioners, lacks all plan and requires no sacrifice. It allows the writer to follow the path of least resistance: everything consists of letting things be. In contrast, narrative, criticism, and essays (almost uncultivated among us), demand preparatory work and organic development." ==Notes== <references /> ==References== * Jorge Luis Borges, [http://www.ciudadseva.com/textos/cuentos/esp/borges/tlon.htm Tlön, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius]. * Martín Prieto, [http://www.clarin.com/suplementos/cultura/2003/02/15/u-00201.htm Memorias de un provinciano], Clarin.com, 15 February 2003, accessed 25 December 2005. * Efemérides (official Argentine government site) page on [http://www.me.gov.ar/efeme/jlborges/amigos.html Algunos amigos e influencias importantes] ("Some important friends and influences [of Jorge Luis Borges]"). {{Authority control|VIAF=44320563}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Mastronardi, Carlos | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1901 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = June 5, 1976 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mastronardi, Carlos}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:Argentine writers]] [[Category:Argentine historians]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]]
